description: From Middle English los, from Old English los (“damage, destruction, loss”), from Proto-Germanic *lusą (“dissolution, break-up, loss”), from Proto-Indo-European *lews- (“to cut, sunder, separate, loose, lose”). Cognate with Icelandic los (“dissolution, looseness, break-up”), Old English lor, forlor (“loss, ruin”), Middle High German verlor (“loss, ruin”). More at lose.

entries.meaning: (countable) The result of no longer possessing an object, a function, or a characteristic due to external causes or misplacement.
examples: loss of limb; weight loss; loss of cognitive functions; loss of appetite.
In other areas, glacier loss creates serious risk of a dry period across the Third Pole, Wang said.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The destruction or ruin of an object.
(countable) Something that has been destroyed or ruined.
examples: It was a terrible crash; both cars were total losses.

entries.meaning: (countable) Defeat; an instance of being defeated.
examples: The match ended in their first loss of the season.

entries.meaning: (countable) The death of a person or animal.
examples: The battle was won, but losses were great.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The condition of grief caused by losing someone or something, especially someone who has died.
examples: Her daughter's sense of loss eventually led to depression.

entries.meaning: (financial, countable) The sum an entity loses on balance.
examples: The sum of expenditures and taxes minus total income is a loss, when this difference is positive.

entries.meaning: (engineering) Electricity of kinetic power expended without doing useful work.
examples: The inefficiency of many old-fashioned power plants exceeds 60% loss before the subsequent losses during transport over the grid.

description: Pronunciation spelling of lost, representing African-American Vernacular English.
